text:
U19
PSG: the youth strategy, a failure?
Several months after deciding to stop the PSG's N2 team to favor the U19, the results are waiting for the young Parisians, even if some failures are to be made with hindsight.
06 Nov 2019, 18:41 by Antoine Chirat



Abdou DialloClub previous: Borussia DortmundIndemnity: 32 million eurosIcon Sport



Idrissa GueyeClub previous: EvertonIndemnity: 30 million eurosIcon Sport



Pablo SarabiaClub previous: Sevilla FCIndemnity: 18 million eurosIcon Sport



Keylor NavasClub previous: Real MadridIndemnity: 15 million eurosIcon Sport



Mauro IcardiClub previous: Inter MilanIndemnity: 5 million euros (loan) Icon Sport



Mitchel BakkerClub previous: Ajax AmsterdamCompensation: noneIcon Sport



Marcin BulkaClub previous: ChelseaIndemnity: noneIcon Sport



Ander HerreraClub previous: Manchester UnitedCompensation: noneIcon Sport



Sergio RicoClub previous: Sevilla FCIndemnity: none (ready) Icon Sport

PSG: all the recruits of the transfer window 2019




What's wrong with U19 PSG? While the "Titis" have always been part of the image of the club, the U19 team coached by St√©phane Roche seems to be struggling at the beginning of the season. As proof, they are almost eliminated from the Youth League after another defeat against Brugge 4-0 (in total, a win for three defeats), and it is little better in the league. Currently, they are in 4th place with already five points behind leader Amiens.




Results to qualify




St√©phane Roche + 9 üì∑Credit Photo - Icon Sport

If these results tend to really surprise, it is that the club management made a real decision regarding the young people last year. Indeed, the Parisian leaders have preferred to abandon the N2 team to focus on the Youth League and the U19 championship, which is for now a failure. However, these last results are to be qualified. Since then, four of the best "Titis" have flown to Brazil and the World Cup: Timoth√©e Pemb√©l√©, Tanguy Nianzou Kouassi, Arnaud Kalimuendo and Adil Aouchiche, all selected for the U17 World Cup.
Another negative effect of the stop of the N2 team, several players from the generation 2000, as Bakker, Bernardou or Sissako for example, are not eligible for the U19 championship and can only take part in the Youth League and 'at the Premier League International Cup (recent competition in the form of a Champions League for the U23). The season is long and judging the new strategy of the club would be too hasty. However, accounts will be requested at the end of the season and changes may occur if the results are not there.
